titlStmt.titl: Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children

citation.biblCit: Robinson, Joan; Lees, Mackenzie; Spady, Don; Seal, Robert; Csanyi-Fritz, Yvonne, 2016, "Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10916, UAL Dataverse, V2

titlStmt.titl: Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children
titlStmt.altTitl: Success of Pediatric Anesthesiologists in Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes

stdyInfo.abstract: The primary purpose of this study was to establish the ability of pediatric anesthesiologists to learn to use two video laryngoscopes - the GlideScope system (GS) and the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface.

sumDscr.universe: 1) Children being intubated for surgery 2) Anesthesiologists who care for children at Stollery Children's Hospital

dataColl.frequenc: Data was collected at baseline and at times of intubation.
dataColl.sampProc: 13 anesthesiologists participated in the study; 14 anesthesiologists agreed to participate, but one relocated before using the VLSs. Data were incomplete for eight other anesthesiologists as there were errors in recording of data or they became reluctant to participate or relocated. All anesthesiologists remained in their assigned groups throughout the study, and none had previous VLS experience. A total of 646 patients were recruited from 2007 through 2011.
dataColl.collSitu: Baseline intubation times, using direct laryngoscopy, were determined for each anesthesiologist on 20 children. Anesthesiologists were then randomized to perform 20 intubations with the GS or KS before crossing over to the other device. The Cormack and Lehane score was compared at baseline and with each of the video laryngoscopes.

setAvail.avlStatus: Data was kept for five years, but has since been destroyed.

citation.biblCit: Lees, M., Seal, R. F., Spady, D., Csanyi-Fritz, Y., Robinson, J. L. (2013), Randomized trial of success of pediatric anesthesiologists learning to use two video laryngoscopes. Pediatric Anesthesia, 23: 435-439.
